summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from May 2019 between employees of SigNet Technologies/Convergint Federal Solutions regarding a past-due, revised invoice for parts. It shows internal business communication about collections and payment status, but contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or his case.

persons.name: Margaret Thornton
persons.context: Employee of SigNet Technologies/Convergint Federal Solutions sending collection emails regarding a past-due invoice for parts.

persons.name: Justin Houston
persons.context: Employee of SigNet Technologies/Convergint Federal Solutions who revised an invoice for parts and is copied on collection emails.

connections.description: Co-workers at SigNet Technologies/Convergint Federal Solutions collaborating on invoice revision and collection efforts.

events.title: Revised Invoice Sent
events.description: Justin Houston sends a revised invoice for parts that have been delivered.

events.title: Invoice Follow-up
events.description: Margaret Thornton follows up on the revised invoice, asking if it has been approved.

events.title: Urgent Collection Request
events.description: Margaret Thornton sends an urgent request for payment review, noting the invoice is for a large sum and is past due.

locations: 12300 Kiln Ct Suite E, Beltsville, MD 20705
keyFacts: The document is a business email chain about collecting payment for a revised invoice for parts.
The correspondence is between employees of SigNet Technologies/Convergint Federal Solutions.
The invoice is described as 'quiet a large sum of money and very much past due' as of May 23, 2019.
There are no mentions of Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, victims, properties, or any related legal matters.
The document appears to be a routine business communication unrelated to the Epstein case.
